description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/3sOvCh510jO
This is a simple smartwatch (SMPL watch) design intended to be printed in ninjaflex filament. The clasp probably needs some work, this is just an idea -- I don't own a 3d printer. I intend to put a oled or eink screen in it and a bluetooth module to sync with a phone along with some sort of low powered mc and a thinergy battery.
To be made via 3d printing with ninjaflex.

comments.text:
Â too early to give a good assessment.
I like some things, but i also liked the replicatorG
faster slicing in the few i tried,
user interface is 'cleaner'
comments.author: matrhint

comments.text: Awesome! Does it have all of the settings pre-set so that there isn't any messing with the skeinforge stuff?
comments.author: cerberus333

comments.text:
Â actually it seems to default to replicator2 settings which need to be adjusted after each launch. I am hoping that they will have it remember the settings so I can leave it at replicator single, ABS and .27 slice as well as the other stuff.Â  not a huge issue but it would be more convenient.
overall it seems decent and once it gets past beta i think it will be a improvement.
my only complaint is the python install sees to conflict with the repG and I can't use rep G without reinstalling python, which MIGHT then cause an issue for makerware (not sure as yet if that is true, but i don't want to spend my time fixing it if it does go awry)

This is a SUNY Albany Keychain made for INF470 Physical Computing class.

Children's House is designed to be assembled without nails, screws or bolts. It's a log cabin for the current century and technology and perhaps a new age of spiritual wisdom. It has 11 bedrooms, 11 bathrooms, a large room with 30 single beds for children, a huge kitchen and an equally large social room. It is like none other. On youtube you can view the 3d walk-thru posted on this site plus two other videos at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eAE5Zt81hzs&feature=youtu.be Right click the link and select 'open in new tab' or 'open in new window' to navigate to YouTube to access the other two videos. If you download the CAD files and have the free CAD viewer from AutoDesk you can open the files and view the house from any angle, walk or fly thru the house or turn off layers to see how the boards connect (e.g., hiding the inside walls, outside walls, beams, roof, etc.). You can also download CAD drawings showing each board's series of required cuts that must be made in a specified order; to both simplify and generalize the cuts for all boards as well as for the tools required to make notches, angle cuts, troughs, etc. As it's designed now, the house is composed of ~7,000 pieces, like an intricate 3d jigsaw puzzle. Given all these boards, cut to specs, the structure is self-straightening, though not self-levelling. Unlike most houses, the entire structure could be disassembled and reassembled without tools (not including sub-systems, such as plumbing). Comments and queries can be sent to [email protected] Enjoy

The house requires both the main 'children's house' file (chouse 367.dwg), and the floor file (floor.dwg) referred to in the main file.  
The floor block is mirrored and polar arrayed 8 times about the house, so there are cuts that weren't made; e.g., the wall support ('h' layer) notches in layer 'b'. Since they don't go into all 8 sections, the main file size would balloon if the floor section was copied to make only some have the notches (I'm not a cad pro, and because I don't want to be, this was already hard enough working in 3d). Without these cuts, the inside walls will not be supported and will not stand.  
The roof structure without nails has not been designed except as 32 3d objects. I imagined the furniture being without nails as well and interlocked into the floor boards.

description.text: My machine came with a broken rod clip under the table, so I printed a new one! Seems to work OK, might need some fine tweaking to make the bed 100% flat.
Just print it... :D Probably full fill and fine to keep dimensions accurate and strength.

comments.text: Thankyou!
comments.author: jackmarshall

comments.text:
It took almost two year until my 3d printed clip was damaged (because I was a little bit hard handed). Anyway, I had my replacement parts that i recieved from the supplier but never used. After 15 minutes of attempts to mount them I gave up and downloaded this file again and held the Y-axis with my bare hands to support it and printed a new one which was mounted in less than 30 seconds....
(Now I've printed a few more as spare for next time....)
comments.author: ahd71

comments.text: Bless you kind person. The ABS cant be any weaker than the factory clips.

we can make it happen.

With the ast explanation from Thingiverse lawyer, things are getting back to normal.

comments.text: See the latest from the Thingiverse blog -->
comments.author: MichaelAtOz

comments.text: Â Doesn't change anything. There is one point doe. Thingiverse needs to have double license. One that you choose and another one that protects you and others when they print or modify your work, without getting one guy suing another or thingiverse.
comments.author: MichaelAtOz

comments.text: I love the idea. Thingiverse has needed some alternatives for a while so it's good recent events prompted this.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: Using a wiki is interesting, but comes with use-ability challenges particularly for new users. My experience with students trying to contribute to wikipedia and appropedia show you will need to develop an intuitive interface and limit all actual markup editing to a minimum or for advanced users. The most successful open source appropriate technology databases are wikis though so there is some precedent - see discussion http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30880http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: jpearce

comments.text: Ah, another Thongiverse and Weaponiverse. We have had people try this before. It usually fails a few days in. When you get started on it you will realize just how much time and effort  and money Makerbot put into developing this website. But good luck anyway.
comments.author: TheMakerGuy

comments.text:
Â It doesn't need to end there. The site is a virtual domain where multiple web apps can run in parallel. I started with a wiki trying to get others to join in the effort of building an organization with non-profit goal, like wikipedia.
A place where projects can evolve and efforts shared.
comments.author: TheMakerGuy

Prusa's original DXF for his Y motor bracket made the curves too chunky for my liking, so I remade it in OpenSCAD. Now I can take full advantage of my firmware's jerk setting and get beautifully smooth curves at full speed. I also added slots so that it's easier to install, or switch for my http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15988 . They're oriented so that as much structural stiffness as possible is retained.

1) Print
2) Observe smooth curves instead of faceted, lumpy ones

There was a single edge razor blade included with my makerbot to use for removing parts from the build platform.  I do not like using a naked blade, and did not have a holder for it, so I made one.

First ensure that the top and bottom parts fit snugly together.  I made them with a very tight fit, so you may need to file them a small amount to get things together.  This is on purpose, to ensure nothing falls out of place.  
Fit the blade into the bottom part, then clip the top part over the blade.

comments.text: Spelled razor wrong, but good idea.
comments.author: CRAZYPRINTR

comments.text: I tried making one of these, but it does not fit the razors I have.  The recess is not long enough for the back end of the razor to fit in there, with the holes in that position.  It seems there's quite a bit of variance in dimensions between different razor blade manufacturers.
comments.author: thehans

comments.text: Seems like this wouldn't be too hard to extend to an actual face-shaving razer, although I'm probably not giving up my multiblade cartridge model any time soon...
comments.author: MaskedRetriever

comments.text: Hmm... That is actually a pretty good idea..  I wonder if I could get the accuracy good enough to print a multi blade razor that works almost as good as the store bought ones.
comments.author: MaskedRetriever

A stylish charging stand for Google Glass - there are two versions:
  • Oval shaped USB cable connector
  • Rectangle shaped USB cable connector
    • Also, the pictures show a customized writing - the STL file here has a neutral "GL/|SS" only.

There are 2 designs, one with an oval shaped cord channel, the other file with a more standard rectangle shape.  
Also, the source files are available in Cubify Invent .fun format.

comments.text: What USB cable are you using? I have a collection of dozens and even the smallest ones won't fit.
comments.author: zackfreedman

comments.text: I'm using an HTC one ( oval shaped) - what are the dimensions of one you are trying to use? I can make an additional version with a channel that holds your connector.
comments.author: zackfreedman

comments.text: Could you just add the model to the Thing files? That way, other hackers and I could make versions to fit our cables.
comments.author: rog0978

comments.text: Can you read / import Cubify Invent .fun files?
comments.author: zackfreedman

comments.text: I prefer to use SketchUp, but I'd download Cubify Invent to customize the model. So might others. It's always good to give the community the choice, unless you have a reason to keep the hackable files private.
comments.author: rog0978

comments.text: OK, uploaded another version with a more standard USB connector size (6.6 x 11.5 mm), plus the source files.
comments.author: zackfreedman

As it just happend to my partner, a yellowjacket was inside the can and unseen, so he was hit twice and survived thanks he had no allergy. To prevent this in future I just designed a cover to stop yellowjackets from entering the can.

You might adjust the size as I designed it for the german Red Bull cola, and I dont know if there are different sizes, or you might use of course for different drinks. Very helpful not only for preventing yellowjackets to get into you drink.

description.text: My Drill Press has seen some hard usage doing awesome projects over the years.  While it resided at NYC Resistor, some of the handles broke over time and use.  I decided to print some new handles for it.  Read more in the instructions.

This has space for a captive nut. I used a 3/8" coupling nut. I filled extra space in the nut with shapelock so I could customize the fit at the drill press. The openscad file is included if you wanted to change the size of the captive nut.

description.text: I am moving this design off of Thingiverse in protest of their attempt to patent designs originally conceived by the 3D printing community. This file can be found on Github at https://github.com/aBrainDump/Misumi-2020-Extrusion-Web-Cam-Stand For more information, please see the following article: http://www.openbeamusa.com/blog/2014/5/22/stay-classy-makerbot

I needed a web cam stand and the spare piece of 2020 I had was just the right height.  So I created 2 versions of the stand in OpenSCAD.  One has 4 legs that I used as the base and the other with 2 legs to hold the web cam.
Printed in PLA .4 layer height
If you're playing Dota 2 and you select or random Nature's Prophet you better meet the quota.

I first obtained my image from this link: http://browse.deviantart.com/?qh=Â§ion=&q=natures+prophet#/d56wkg4 Once I downloaded the image I put it in Photoshop to get one frame out of it since it was gif. I tried to Rasterize the image as it was with 100 speed and 50 power, but ended up with a very faded finish. I then croped the background out and edited the image in Illustrator with Livetrace. I set the speed to 100 and the power to 60, I still wasn't satisfied with the results. With my final print I set the speed to 100 and the power to 70 and finally ended up with nice results as you can see with the uploaded images on here.

This is a small wooden plaque that I rastered using the Epilog CNC Laser that we are fortunate enough to have at school. Usually when you play a high school sport, at the end of the season, the team gives the coach a gift. As part of that gift, I wanted to make a plaque for our coach. I thought that it would be a very unique and personalized gift for her. As you can see, it reads RHS Girl's Tennis Coach, Coach Devin and has two tennis racquets on it.

I started making this by taking a precut wooden block (one that already looked like a plaque) and measuring its length and width. I then made an Adobe Illustrator file that had the same dimensions. From there it was just a matter of typing in the text with a solid font, finding a nice picture of two crossed tennis racquets and putting a contemporary border around it. After a bit of tweaking at the border and experimenting with the font size, I was finally done and I printed it out using an Epilog CNC Laser.

Variation of (with much thanks to):

    • This model was based on juniortan\'s.
    I didn\'t have even 1mm brass rods, so I made more simple variation - without any rods.
This model is able to use instead of z float.STL , Wobble Arrester.

description.text:
This is a super-simple belt driven syringe-based extruder for viscous or non-newtonian fluids such as peanut butter. it uses the MakerBot MK6's 100oz-in stepper motor to provide the necessary force, and applies pressure to the syringe via the mechanical advantage of a belt based reduction. This potentially also increases the resolutuon of the steps/volume, but very little experimentation has been done with fine control of the flow rate.
This model was designed around scraps I happened to have laying around, but it works really well.
This extruder was co-designed with Scott Beibin in July 2012, specially for use in the Groucho Fractal Show - www.grouchofractal.com

Note: You may need to modify the SCAD to tightly fit your syringe.
The SCAD file relies on thing:19758 and on MCAD, https://github.com/elmom/MCAD
You will also need:
One high-torque stepper motor (for example http://www.anaheimautomation.com/products/stepper/stepper-motor-item.php?sID=69&pt=i&tID=75&cID=19 ), or scavenged from a MakerBot MK6 extruder
Four M3x10 bolts for mounting the motor
One 20mL syringe, with a 20mm OD
One M8 ID 26mm OD "skate" bearing
One large 5mm ID 16mm OD GT2 pulley
About 300mm of GT2 Belt (Cut to length as needed)
One 4mm ID 16mm OD bearing
One M4x15 to mount the bearing
Two M1x20 (probably) to mount the clamp
Assembly is easy, the pulley is attached to the motor, the motor is bolted to the main block, the belt is clamped on the right side, and then the idler is bolted to the block. The belt is fed into the pulley/idler and then the syringe and plunger pusher are mounted on top. The belt rests on top, kept under some small tension before use. I never designed a way to mount this to a printer (sorry) so I just zip-tied it down. It was a bit of a rushed job.
All I had to do for printing was tell Slic3r I had a 2mm nozzle and 16mm filament, as this best modeled my syringe. In addition, reversal must be totally disabled, or the pusher will fall off.

description.text:
The stock buttons on the space navigator bug me. They take too much force to press for their size (they're uncomfortable) and you have to squeeze the whole device to use them - you have to press them horizontally. This is an attempt to fix these issues.
  • I want the buttons to have a much larger surface area - to make them less pointy and thus more comfortable to press.
  • I want the buttons to actuate vertically, so that the actuation force is toward the desk rather than trying to slide the device around. This has an added benefit of making the buttons usable without repositioning your hand on the device.
    • 4/23: I'm nearly finished, but have been dragging a bit lately, so I thought I'd toss what I have so far online and see if anyone has input. 4/30: It's functional, at least in sketchup. I printed out a set, though I suppose the limitations of 3D printing got me, at least in part. The flappy button levers don't reach the tactile buttons on the PCB properly... The large external buttons don't have enough travel to reach the levers. I'm thinking I'll add adjustment screws (M3 grub screws) to clean up any free play. The buttons also need slides of some sort - the outside edge of the button tilts down and the legs kick inward when the end of travel is reached... Should be fairly easy to fix.

description.text: This was made for my final project in my 3D Printing class. It is a functional miniature bicycle with moving handle bar, moving wheels, moving crank, and moving pedals. Spinning the pedals spins the back wheel once a rubber band is added. Assembly required. Some sanding  required as well. All bike parts were taken from AutoDesk and constructed in TinkerCAD.

The handlebar must have supports and must have the supports fully removed and sanded. The large cylinder in the "all_pedal_parts" file connects the two cranks. The part in "all_pedal_parts" that holds the chain and has a hole going through it entirely will go on the large cylinder next to the right crank. The other part that holds the chain (with a hole going through half-way) will need to be glued to one of the axels, on the outside of the right side of the frame. Then one wheel will need to be glued to that axel, on the inside of the right side of the frame. The other axel will need to be shortened and glued to the other wheel to be put in the fork connected to the handlebar. The small rods in "all_pedal_parts" go through the foot pedals and into the small hole in cranks. You will need to sand some of the pedal parts.  
Instead of sanding the axels, you could make the holes bigger for the front and back wheel axels in the handlebar and frame (in a modeling software or with a power drill like I did).  
Make sure the back wheel is aligned as perfectly as possible with minimal rubbing on the frame when spun. This is the trickiest part. Attach a small rubber band to the pedal and back wheel to make sure the back wheel spins easily.  
Then when you have the back wheel ready and the handlebar ready, you are ready to glue the two frame halves. When glueing, make sure the handlebar is in place and the back wheel axel is in place. Then the left crank and pedal can go on, glued if needed. When the rubber band is attached, you should have a fully operational miniature bicycle!

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

Recent developments in OpenSCAD have made it possible to make arbitrary, programmatic polygons. In the past, you had to kludge this with boolean unions of many 3d volumes, but now you can do this in a recursive loop. This makes things which used to be painful, simple; things which used to take minutes to render, fast enough to animate. So here, have a mathematically-modelled gerotor.

You will need an extremely recent version of openscad to use this.  I use 2014-04-10 experimental.  
You will need to edit -> preferences -> features, check 'concat', to allow OpenSCAD to build arrays in runtime.

title: The Helping M
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Helping M is a very portable clamp to help you hold in components during soldering jobs. I started on this after hand-soldering the 52 SMT components for the HBP :-P
  • There is no need to bend the component wires to hold in the component during soldering
  • Adapts to different sizes of circuit boards: Max about 7 to 8 inches wide
  • With some velco, interchangeable heads allow usage for capacitors, resistors, ICs
  • Once mounted, The Helping M is able to move laterally to press on different components
  • The Helping M slides up and down your board easily too
  • The Helping M also serves as a prop when you flip the circuit board around, to position the board in the right position to solder easily

• Print - everything is on one sheet, and fits the Cupcake
  • Glue in the two shortest stubs onto the circuit board clamps
  • Glue in the two slightly bigger stubs onto the head
  • Get some bungie cord and one of those bungie cord locking thingies you find in backpacks
  • Cut some thin sheet metal to hold the bungie cords to the bolts on the joint (see pictures)
  • Assemble everything using M3x12 screws (you will need 6 bolts and nuts)
  • There are 2 attachment adapters for the heads - one with a hollowed square, one with a U shaped channel. Fill them up with some foam to hold different components. These can be attached to the head with velcro.
    • Additional Notes:
  • For the sheet metal, i just cut up a soft drink can
  • All bolts/nuts should give the joints free play of movement - the bungie/angles provide the forces necessary to hold the circuit board/components - use some Locktite to secure the nuts
  • I usually brush everything with some acetone for strength; especially the clamps

description.text:
Running off my proton pack, here is the wand! As with the proton pack, this is a work in progress. Right now, this is just a model of the gun. I will be going back and polishing up the other parts and uploading them as separate parts (namely the knobs, heatsink, and grips) Few things to point out again:
  • This is made using plans from GBFans. For this, I used mostly Sean's plans, with a touch of Norms and Stefan's
  • MAJOR work in progress.
  • This is in a 1:25 scale. Long story short, my CAD units are screwy, so I draft 1:1, but in reality, it's actually 1:25. I've tried fixing it, but it always reverts back...
  • The parts are not 10% accurate. This is due to the fact that there is not solid "this parts goes there" plan.
  • And, if you want to look to make your own plans, go to the instructions of proton pack I have made. I have a few good links on there on how to make the whole pack.

The Snooze iPhone Stand allows you to access Siri and the home button by pushing down on a big button that is part of the stand.
Set up your iPhone 5 horizontally at night as a visible alarm clock, and when the alarm goes off, groggily smack the big button and tell Siri, "Wake me up in 5 minutes!" No need to remove the iPhone from the stand or fumble for the tiny button.
Best for the iPhone 5, 5s, or 5c. Works with a case on.

If you find that the case is too tight and constantly pushes the home button because you use a thicker case for your phone, try sanding the tip that pushes on the button. A little adjustment can make a big difference.
If your nightstand is on the left side of the bed, print this mirrored so that your phone will be oriented correctly when laying down.

title: Marblevator "Mini", Zigzag Edition Track
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A Zigzag track for the Marblevator "Mini", Bowl Edition base.
Video of prototype here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Una3DxiP2_o. If I counted correctly, eight marbles (9.5mm or 3/8" ball bearings) were on the track. Works great with 1 to 8 marbles at 1.5vdc, and 1 to 12 marbles at 3vdc (although at the higher voltage, you may loose your marbles).
Uses the base assembly ("Base.stl", "Gear Crown.stl", "Gear Motor.stl" and "Gear Worm.stl") from the original Marblevator "Mini", Bowl Edition. If you've already built the Marblevator "Mini", Bowl Edition then simply push out the worm gear and track, then install this track assembly and replace the worm gear; takes about 20 seconds or so. If not, build the Marblevator "Mini", Bowl Edition first.
Prints in two pieces that are snapped together.
And finally, if you don't mind manual labor, the hand cranked version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:310488.
Printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" settings.

Print the two pieces, press together, then install on your Marblevator "Mini" base.  The press points are a tight fit, so some trimming may be necessary depending on your printer, printer settings, and colors.

author: thofst

title: PodBreakout to iPod Touch V4 rigid docking port

description.text:
The PodBreakout plug allows experimenters to connect the 30 pin iPod socket to external devices, such as a microcontroller. However, it is an ungainly shape and the full 30 pin version has a circuit board of solder terminals that sticks out of the back of the plug, rendering it susceptible to damage.
This docking port allows you to glue the PodBreakout in place at one end, holds the cable securely, and is shaped to allow you to slide an iPodTouch into a socket at the other end so that it connects accurately with the plug and keeps the whole assembly securely connected.

This was tricky to design to avoid curling at the ends when being printed. It has 1mm thick "mouse ears" on each corner to help keep the corners stuck down when the first few layers are being printed. First 2mm of underside are hollow to reduce warping. Prints OK with a raft. I used heated bed at 110 degrees and extrusion temperature of 225 degrees (MakerBot Replicator). Sides of MakerBot enclosed to keep heat inside. When printed glue the PodBreakout white plug into the centre recess, and before glue is set, gently slide the iPodTouch into the right hand slot on device and partially push it onto the end of the 30 pin plug. This way you know the glue will set holding the plug in exactly the correct position so that in future the iPod will always connect with the plug each time you insert it.
Edges of the slot fold over the sides of the iPod so it will not fall out. If you like the whole assembly can be built into a larger device leaving just the open socket on one side to insert the iPod.

title: Make stronger parts with your replicator

description.text:
Ok so I own 4 mendel maxs  but before those amazing machines I had bought a Replicator for work.   I vowed that I would probally let it collect dust before using it again.  UNTIL I got bored.    So the difference is the strength of the parts and the angle at which the fill gets filled.    For those that don't build other printers and own a replicator you would have no idea what the grass looks like on the other side.       So here is what you do if you have always relied on replicatorG and have never known how to slice any other way.
This is not a model but a way to make you models stronger if you only own a replicator.        There are other ways to do this but I wanted it to be simple for people that dont know much about slicing.

First before you start
build a 20 x 20 X 5 and print it on the replicator. Take a pair of cutters and cut it in half.... Then Find the skeinforge profile for replicator. Here it is on a mac (see pictures) . Your looking for fill.csv under skeinforge 5.0 Your mission is simple..... Change 90 degrees to 45 Degrees in fill. Infill Begin Rotation (degrees): 45 After which I would like you to build a 20 x 20 X 5 cube and try and cut it. Ok so lesson is simple. Angles = strength. Print your favorite model and tell me what you think ;) I had to divide the pictures up a little to make the readable... Follow step 1 and step 2 pictures if you cant find the file. On a PC its pretty freeken easy to find.. It will still sound like a rickity old bus being hit by a train but now at least the parts will be stronger ;) enjoy

comments.text: I tried this, looking at a calibration cube. I couldn't see any difference in the fill before and after. I had restarted RepG, and opened fill.csv again to make sure the change was there.
comments.author: Darrellandson

comments.text: I don't have the restriction you are detailing here but perhaps you could post some nice pictures of some parts you have cut up.
comments.author: Conseils

The Printrbot Simple XL comes with provisions for a roll of filament. Out of the three rolls I currently have not a single one sits on the rollers properly. I wanted something to allow me to quickly change rolls out. That got me thinking - where else in life do people want to quickly and easily change rolls out? Then it hit me - Toilet paper! I designed this stand to sit on top of the XL and be somewhat held in place by the bearings on top. There is a cutout for the Z screw so it sits flat on top. The fixture uses a standard toilet paper roller that can be picked up at a hardware store for a few bucks (or "borrowed" from the hall bathroom). Based on the fact that before I printed this out I literally had filament spools hanging from the chandelier over my dining room table I don't think my wife will complain too much about the missing roller in the hall restroom! This fixture is a bit on the tall side so you will need an XL to print it out. I have ran a few prints with it and have not seen any feed issues! EDIT: 4/26/2014
Revision 2 uploaded
Revision 2 is shorter so you can print it on an XL without removing the top plate. It has a clearance hole in the bottom, and better support for the uprights. UPDATE 4/29/2014
Revision 3 uploaded
Revision 3 is a bit taller then Revision 2. Revision 2 worked with all spools I had at the time but I recently got spools that are the same height but the hole in the middle is larger, causing them to hang lower and rub. I also increased the size of the clearance hole on the bottom hoping to make it easier to line it up. As these things take forever to print out I haven't printed Rev 3 yet so if someone prints it let me know how the hole in the bottom lines up!

Print out fixture.  
I used an infill of 50% and it took a LONG time - about 17 hours to print.  That was revision 1 and revision 2 is smaller so it should print a little quicker.  
Place fixture on top of machine being careful to line up clearance hole on the bottom of the fixture with the Z axis screw that protrudes through the top of the machine.  
Borrow toilet paper roller from nearest restroom (or purchase from local hardware store).  
Insert toilet paper roller through filament spool  
Insert toilet paper roller and filament spool in to fixture  
Feed filament as before

comments.text:
Your info seems to indicate that in version 1 it was necessary to take the top off but not with version 2 which is shorter but then version 3 is taller than version 2. So is there need to remove the top for version 3? I don't see any call outs in the Instructions but I believe the instructions were last updated for version 2.
Thanks.
comments.author: chester40391

comments.text: No, you do not need to remove the top on version 3.

title: Electric Chair
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a rough model of Old Sparky. It is a bit macabre but it was good fun to make. I am an electrician and work with the police so this kind of represented electricity and crime. Did you know that the modern electric chair runs at 2000 volts at about 6-8 amps.
Print, stick and paint

comments.text: The model is made qualitatively. But diz like, the idea is cruel.
comments.author: Shizo

comments.text: NOT A METHOD OF EXECUTION i WOULD CHOOSE if i HAD TO CHOOSE ONE OF COURSE
comments.author: Shizo

comments.text:
Sorry about that
The back section has now been added to the files. Did not show a picture of it but I downloaded the file and all good.
Let me know if you have any more missing files.

comments.text: Is there a chair back part? I don't see it in the downloadable models...

comments.text: That is amazing. Did you have plans on it's construction or did you use reference pictures?
comments.author: MustangDave

comments.text:
Hi Dave
Sorry about the delay in the reply Dave but I have been on holiday over seas for a few weeks. I made this from a 3d picture I found on a web site called Grab Cad which had a 3d picture of the chair. I then imported the picture into Google Sketch up and proceeded to make each part into a printable stl file. After a lot of work, the end result is as shown. It is based on a historic electric chair called OLD SPARKY!.

comments.text: No problem! I am very impressed with it, looks almost real.

iPhone5 case with 5mm on all sides.  My previous iphone5 case was 8mm, which is rather bulky, but fit in my hands nicely.  the case i liked for my iphone4 was about 4.5mm, which was nice and solid, but interfered with the flash.  This case does not.  It also has more clearance for the front camera and ambient light sensor.

You will need 24 2-56 SHCS (Socket Head Cap Screws)
they may be purchased here: mcmaster.com/#98511A133

This is my first thing and more of an experiment with Solidworks, my RepRapPro Huxley, and Thingverse but I hope it will be useful to someone as well. I have used it for holding gluing models. This is a printable G clamp which consists of any metric machine screw and nut and a printed "G".
I have set it up using well labeled equations in Solidworks so you can easily resize it for any metric size. It comes set up for M4.

• Open the Solidworks file and go to Tools> Equations
  • Edit the relevant numbers to apply to the nut and bolt size you are using. Close equations and watch the part auto update
  • Save STL and print
    • If you want to use an m4 nut and bolt in your mini G clamp you can just print the provided STL

remixed_from.author: richgain
remixed_from.title: eMaker Huxley Part Cooling Fan Mount

description.text:
I made this fan mount for my RepRapPro Huxley. It holds a PC fan at 45 degrees (to point towards the hot end better). The stl is set up for a 60mm PC fan but can be changed in the solidworks part file.
Thanks to Richgain for the idea - I just customised all the dimensions for my much larger PC graphics card fan I had.

• Edit the solidworks file to fit fan dimensions and print or just print STL
  • Screw fan onto mount with two M3 machine screws and nuts
  • Screw to back of the X Idler of your RepRap Huxley (use longer m3 screw if necessary)
    • [FOR REPRAPPRO SANGUINOLOLO 1.3 ELECTRONICS RUNNING SPRINTER}
  • Wire the fans red cable to +12 and the black to gnd on the connector marked PWR2/Bed which is between the board power connector and hotend connector. See this site for more information. http://www.splitbrain.org/blog/2012-03/24-reprap_huxley_cooling_fans
    If you have a fan with a yellow cable also - ignore it. This is the tacho signal which provides feedback of the fans speed and not used here.
  • Test the fan. Sent M106 S255 to turn it on full, M106 S127 to turn it on half way, M107 to turn it off
  • Enable cooling settings in your slicer and enjoy your new fan in future prints

title: HPI Firestorm Front Arm Pivot Pin Cover

description.text:
This is the front plastic cover for the front arm pivot pins on the HPI Firestorm. It is just a cap which stops the pin pivot which joins the wheel arm to the body coming out.
The original is one piece, this replacement is separated so you can just print one when only one side brakes, just install the other way up for the other side.

• Print the part and a couple of spares for your box
  • Enjoy running without having to pay extortionate prices for a tiny piece of plastic every time you have a minor crash head on
  • Work on getting better at driving in the extra uptime you have so you don't even need to print parts in the future! (Thats the dream)

title: Aluminium Square Tube Connectors - Parametric SCAD Library

description.text:
Plastic connectors for Aluminium* square tube. Or printable square tube. Similar to those used to assemble furniture from the homeware store. Qubelok being one type http://www.fairlite.com.au/qubelok.html There is a zip of the STLs down the bottom of the list. One-inch or 25.4mm profile as writen, but you can change size via OpenSCAD. The SCAD has callable modules to model the connectors and the tube profile and a print module to split a part in half and rotate for 3D printing. Work in progress, probably needs refining. I'm also working on a hollow version so cables etc can pass through the joins. But no promises.
  • aluminum if you don't speak true English ;^}

UPDATE Feb 2013: I finally got around to printing some, they turned out well, see photos. They fit nicely into the tube, but don't lock-in like the original. I'll try a version with the small bulge that does the press fit, stay tuned. ps Don't print totally hollow, slic3r was printing in thin air.
To test un-star the sqDemo call, un-star one (only one) of the lines below sqPrint, or call as appropriate from your own SCAD file, and export a STL.
The STLs, mostly, have been cut to print properly and need another part to glue on the bottom. For example a 180 joiner needs two halves printed, the join3 needs a join90 on the bottom. Some combinations allow you to choose a specific print grain, eg two join90s, or a join90b + an End-Cut both make a 90 degree join.
Alternatively you can print Block & Insert and glue together as needed.
Print & glue halves together.
I haven't done complex models with this yet, but to help I kept the larger cube section at the origin to hopefuly help with translation etc.

title: RAPIRO - The Humanoid Robot for your Raspberry Pi

description.text:
RAPIRO is a cute and affordable robot kit designed to work with a Raspberry Pi. It comes with a Arduino-compatible servo controller. http://www.rapiro.com
  • Comes with 12 servo motors and full-color LED of eyes.
  • Easy assembly. Anyone can assemble a RAPIRO with only a screwdriver, without the need for any soldering.
  • The servo control board is programmable and is completely compatible with the Arduino.
  • Designed to mount the Raspberry Pi and Camera module in the head.
  • Designed to mount a PSD distance sensor and speakers.

You have to buy following parts to assemble the robot. 6 large servos: http://international.switch-science.com/catalog/1659/
6 small servos: http://international.switch-science.com/catalog/1658/
6 large servo arm sets:
6 small servo arm sets:
A Rapiro board: http://international.switch-science.com/catalog/1632/
A Rapiro LED board:
A switch cable:
A 5-pole cable L=250mm:
A 6-pole cable L=250mm:
28 tapping screws 3-6mm:
18 tapping screws 2-7mm:
30 tapping screws 2-5mm:
*Battery contacts

comments.text: I'm a little surprised at the negativity towards this. Sure, it may be a commercial product (and an expensive one at that), and the files may not be immediately printable, but I think it's really cool that the people behind it are willing to share their design like this. Even if it just serves as a jumping-off point for others, it's still good for the thingiverse community.
comments.author: aherbez

comments.text: I'm not concerned about the parts not being 'printable' because they are printable with smarter slicers that give more control over support (e.g. Simplify3D, Up!).
comments.author: laird

comments.text:
It's great that they released the models. And I'm not concerned that it's not designed for printability - with files out, others can make derivatives that are more printable. And there are slicers, such as Simplify3D, that do a much better job of support than the free options, so perhaps this could push the free options to improve the intelligence of their support generation.
The only drawback I see is that Rapiro is only sold as a complete kit with all of the parts, including the body parts. And, in particular, it's tied to a servo controller that is (as far as I can tell) only available from Rapiro, so you can't print the parts here, buy the servos, Raspberry Pi, etc., and build a robot, because you're missing their controller.
So right now these parts are only useful for people who buy the whole kit, which includes these parts, and who then prefer to use printed parts.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: To correct myself - I double checked, and while they didn't before, now they DO sell the controller by itself ($60) which means that you can print the parts, and assemble your own Rapiro using your own servos, Pi, etc.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: Because it looks pretty on the front page. I agree, this is most definitely not optimized for printing, and it is not a practical project to follow really, the cost is far from affordable (in reality you can buy a 3D printer, or even a Robot prebuilt) for close to that final figure. title: Mendel Snap-in Filament Spool Holder Adapter

description.text: This is an additonal Wheel and Filament Holder Adapter that allows using the small 1 Kg spools from RepRapWorld by using the adapters on the RepRapLogo and adding two 608 bearings to the RepRapWorld Wheel and mount as shown in the pictures.

Print out two RepRapWorld Wheels and four RapRapWorld filament holder adapters.
Press one 608 bearing into each of the wheels while they are hot off the printer (they just slide right in). Mount a RepRapWorld 1Kg spool in the exact middle of a 24cm long piece of 8mm threaded rod. Insert one RepRapWorld Wheel from each side with the 608 bearing facing out. Now from each side add an 8mm washer and an 8mm nut und tighten. Now add from each side an 8mm nut, 8mm washer and a RepRapWorld filament holder with the round side facing towards the spool. This should be brought as close to the spool as possible. Now slide one end of the threaded rod through the RepRap Logo hole in the Mendel Snap-in Filament Spool Holder so that you can then put the other end in the RepRap Logo hole on the other side. Center the threaded rod and then slide the RepRapWorld filament holder (aligned with the RepRap Logo hole) such that it snaps into the hole on each side flush. Now move then nuts outward until it exerts pressure on the adapters. Now from the outside on each side add an 8mm washer and an 8mm nut and tighten hand tight. Now use a wrench on each side of the left side and tighten the nuts against each other (not too tight) and then do the same for the other side.

title: Small footprint J-head quick fit extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Smaller version of Olekdh's extruder keeping all the good bits like the tilting screws, j-head lock plate and clean printing body.
The intention is to make an x-carriage that will take two of these either nose to tail or, if I can work out how to do it, mirror image. I have rotated and moved the motor to allow the rear mount to be moved closer and shorten the whole baseplate, and should make it possible to mount these forward to back on the x-carriage. Also has the standard 50mm spacing mounting screws too so will replace any standard extruder. Quick fit latch here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31528

Print out all the parts and fit them together, you will probably have to run a drill through the holes to clear them.
This is now a working extruder so I have removed the work in progress tag. Use the standard Wade gears from one of the predecessors.

comments.text: Corrected body STL uploaded, had a support material issue. I have deleted the earlier version of the body to avoid confusion.
comments.author: Wired1

comments.text: I am having trouble printing this. Â I tied slicing with both skeinforge and slic3r with the same basic issues. Â First, the face down bearing opening offers no support for the smaller opening above it. Â I can get around this by generating support with the slicer. Â The second problem is bigger. Â The part that the idler connects to is also printed without any underlying support. Â It looks like you started to have something there, but both slic3r and skeinfirge render this as hollow which means 1) that it offers no support, and 2) the slicer does not know it needs to generate support.
comments.author: jbernardis

comments.text: I have uploaded the latest version of the body as well as the same file in STEP format which seems to be the only default file type we can all read. There is support material built in and it slices correctly on 0.9.3 Slic3r for me. Good luck and let me know if it still gives you grief :)

This derivative is the same as the original - just three corners into one file to print them in one go.

For details details, refer to the original Thing by DDStarkey.
I've published both the Sketchup design file and resulting STL export.  
Note 1: The Sketchup STL export seems to cause error messages in ReplicatorG when generating gCode, however it works fine when I printed it.
Note 2: My Replicator has several adhesive tabs keeping the cables in place - bear in mind the height of these plugs may mean you need to move the lowest tab up a bit so they go in okay.
After a couple of prints you might want to know how much filament is left on your spool. This little device helps to stabalize the spool on a digital scale (without rolling of the scale)

Simply print out the part using your favourite settings. Use an infill-% of about 20%.
After printing put it on your digital scales, set them to "0" and put on the filament spool. Note the weight of the unused spool on the spool label so you know what the gross weight of the spool including filament is. In my case it was 1225 grams.
By weighing the filament-spool after printing a couple of other things you can always determine how much filament is used an how much should be left. In my case this was 1225 - 1054 = 171 grams used, thus left 1000 - 171 = 829 grams, enough for a lot more printing fun ;-)

title: Printrbot LC X Carriage Printed Part Conversion

description.text: Lose the old X carriage and replace it with the original printed part (modified design). At the same time replace the X Beam to move the endstop further to the left in a more comfortable position and for more build space. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gYjC3zPaXmI

Remove the old X carriage and X beam.  Fit the new X beam and secure endstop in new position with M2.5 bolts. Slide on the new X carriage and position belt with clamp. Done!
Of course you will need the original PB Extruder Mount which is included here in the files for your convenience.
The new X Beam just has the endstop holes moved so just drill the new holes carefully if you cant source a new laser cut part. The new X Carriage part has a small notch for hitting the newly placed endstop which must coincide with eachother obviously.
The new black front securing plates shown in the pic are just so I can use M3.5x37 countersunk bolts in my design and are not essential to this mod.

comments.text: My opinion is that the entire top X section need re-thinking because the ends bend in like a crossbow when the belt is pulled together. It is just a slight bowing at first but gets worse over time. Really there should be two paralell beams rather than just one Or redesign it so the smooth rods cover the entire distance of the beam to double as re-enforcement to stop it bowing. After such a mod then yes, perhaps.Â  The printrbot is a very promising simple design that I think should get lots of attention. My hat off to Brook for inspiring me to build and modify my first bot!

Here is a simple openSCAD program which outputs the "dual" of a set of points on a unit sphere. If the points are the vertices of an Archimedean solid the output is a Catalan solid. If the points are a solution to the Thomson problem, (see thing:22663, Thomson Problem Polyhedra), the output is the convex hull dual. If the points are the centers of the faces of a polyhedron all equidistant from the origin, the output
is the polyhedron. More than one set of points can be used as input so as to output compound polyhedra or material common to two or more polyhedra. For example the Archimedean polyhedra cannot be output directly as their faces are not equidistant from the origin. However the Archimedean solids can be generated by treating each set of faces separately and combining them. Some sample scad files and their outputs are provided. They are: A program to generate a cuboctahedron from its face centers:
cuboctahedron_to_self.scad A program to generate a rhombic dodecahedron from the vertices of the cuboctahedron:
cuboctahedron_to_dual.scad A program to generate the cuboctahedron - rhombic dodecahedron compound:
compound_cuboctahedron_dual.scad A program to generate the material common to a cuboctahedron and a rhombic dodecahedron:
common_cuboctahedron_dual.scad The image at the upper left shows the four polyhedra. Note how the vertices of the cuboctahedron protrude through the centers of the faces of the rhomic dodecahedron in the compound polyhedron.

Compound_cuboctahedron_dual.stl needs to be printed with external support.
I don't guarantee that my views of what is going on here are correct as openSCAD often surprises me.  The method used involves two concentric spheres, one arbitrary, and a unit sphere containing the points to be considered.  A vector is drawn from the origin through a point on the unit sphere.  At some distance away from the origin but less than the radius of the arbitrary sphere, a plane normal to the vector is created.  All material that lies beyond the outer side of the plane is removed.  The process is repeated until all of the points have been treated.
Similar results can be obtained with polyhedron commands but I like the simplicity of the method and the fact that it lets openSCAD work out all the triangles.  Perhaps the method has other advantages.

title: Micro USB carkit holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a charger with my carkit holder, but these are not most of the time not universal and quite expensive when you buy it for your phone model. ( I got the SIII and it was like 55,- Euro)
So I got myself a cheap carkit, and printed out a micro usb holder so I can click in the phone everytime I get in the car so I don't have to look for the cable to plug it in first, then put it in my carkit.

• Print it
  • apply little bit of glue
  • click
  • charge :)
    p.s. I could have made holes for holding the parts instead of glue, but there is not much room, I would have to make the part larger etc.. 9
    I've used it for an Galaxy S2 and S3, but I don't see a problem using other phones since the usb slot is centered

title: Desktop CNC/3d Printer (concept)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This was one of my first concepts to make a small desktop CNC / 3d printer.  It uses wood "click" system for most parts, and the design speaks for it self.
This is only a concept, although by now I've seen similar ones on the net which look like this one, it has been attempted by others.

I had to remove the files because I don't like to transfer the ownership of the my personal creations to an entity which claims to be open, profiting from the community, and turns it's back to it. If you wish to have access to the files, you can download them for free from here;
http://dl.dropbox.com/u/89714714/final.zip

So I've been on a roll of sorts with making models for Ghostbuster props. As such, this is the third file: the ghost trap!
As with the other two plans, there are some things to point out:

  • This is in a 1:25 scale. Blame my broken CAD
  • This is not 100% accurate!! Right now, it is missing the knobs on the very front of it. The screen (same side, above the knobs) is also a tad off.
  • MAJOR work in progress. Parts will be pulled off this to be printed and added to a MDF/ply frame
    And, for the rest to the set, I have a collection going!

The product was created in order to provide an alternative to the traditional breadboard. It was produced with the intention of enhancing the Arduino prototyping environment for both educators and hobbyists by addressing common breadboard problems.   
A metal flight case serves as the enclosure for the hardware involved; components have been mounted onto an acrylic panel. Each of the components included are linked to audio-jack ports that are patched to the Arduino in order to create a circuit. The box includes a number of input sensors and output actuators, which can be patched across to the Arduino in order to create a variation of different prototype circuits.

Step One
Use a laser cutter to create the panel Step Two
All components are labelled on the panel. Attach each component to the relevant spot using either super glue or the nuts provided upon purchase. Step Three
Attach the Arduino in the centre of the board using long screws so that the Arduino hangs some distance below the panel. Step Four
Use a length of wire to connect each of the components ground pins to the wire using solder and a soldering iron. Lead this wire through all components and then back to the GND pin of the Arduino. Step Five
Similarly attach a length of wire to all of the components power pins. Lead this pin back to the 5V port on the Arduino. Step Six
Mount the blocks of wood onto the base of the box and then attach the panel to the box

description.text:
Hi, just want to show you a new project I'Âve almost finished:
The pLamp features are:
-3-channel brightness control (each two of the bulbs are separately dimmable)
-adjustable focus position via stepper driven mechanic (see pictures)
-wireless remote controlled (3channel brightness + focus position)
-remote can be hooked to a computer to control the lamp via client.
-most parts are 3d-printed, the rest of them are easy to gather
-6 Standard 5W Led GU5.3 bulbs It was originally designed to be a living room lamp, but with color filters
(different color attached to each channel) plus a small disco ball, it think it's a nice disco lamp too:) http://frankpiesik.info/2014/04/24/plamp/

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/4ofIStkP7AL
I made this to show a friend what possibly could be done with tilt/shift lenses. He owned a nikon. I don't, so I was never able to finish this project to something very useful and safe to use.
The fittings are to loose, so keep hands on lens and body.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Use a dark colour
I just took a caliper and measured the lens roughly. That is the main reason why this fits so bad. Also my first try of tinkercad

comments.text: I had some fit issues too!  The lens side was super loose, basically had to hold the lens on to keep from falling off.  The camera body side seemed odd, no flat base to push up against, and the cutouts for the tabs seemed odd too.  When I got it in, seemed to flop all over the place!  Nice concept, but I think I'll need to make a few mods to get it to work for me!

title: Jeep Wrangler TJ and Cherokee Lift pucks

description.text:
These are coil spring spacers to lift your 1997-2006 Wrangler or Cherokee front springs 2".
They have been tested to withstand 1650 psi printed with PLA @ 10% infill before deforming. Each puck should be able to support 12,900 lbs before deforming.
These have not been tested yet in the real world, I'll be installing them this weekend to test them out. Print and use at your own risk!
This was just an experiment to see if it could be done, turned out better than expected!
UPDATE 5/9/2014
These have been installed for two weeks now on a test Jeep and they're holding up perfectly. They've been down washboard dirt roads, bumpy trails and even a few street potholes. No signs of deformation, cracks, or other failures. LONG TERM UPDATE 7/5/2014
Failure! I had a right rear puck collapse, so I reprinted one with 50% infill and it collapsed within days. After trying to figue out why one puck was collapsing, I drove the Jeep from work to home, then immediately put the FLiR camera on it and it dawned on me - the right rear puck was just a few inches away from the exhaust, which is plenty warm enough to allow the plastic to deform! I've since bought a polyurethane spacer for the rears. The front pucks are holding up excellently, even at 10% infill. Neither of the left rear pucks collapsed, but the springs did leave an imprint in the pucks, which was expected. These pucks in a Cherokee should be A-OK since they are only used in the front. If you insist on running these in a Wrangler, I would suggest some sort of heat shield around the exaust whee it passes over the axle.
Printed a pair at a time on a MakerBot Replicator 5th Gen. with PLA. 100 mm/s extrude, 200 mm/s travel, 10% infill, 6 shells, .2mm layer height.

I do not live in very hot environment, but being parked under the sun for the whole day could get car quite hot..
comments.author: mrdROb

comments.text: I printed them with PLA and they (the fronts) worked fine for almost 2 years. The right rear collapsed due to the heat of the exhaust right next to it. I live in Florida, so we get plenty of hot days and didn't notice any ill effects due to weather temps.

comments.text: Dear friend:
comments.author: Fuchs_71

comments.text:
I must admit this is a good concept, but please don't use these on public streets. If one of these fail, it could end up hurting someone. This should be tested extensively before actual street use.
2 inches seems like a trivial height gain, but it could still cause significant damage to the vehicle. i.e., u-joints, bushings, tie rod ends, and bearings just to name a few.
comments.author: RossRobotics

comments.text: I agree, I would not trust 3D printed parts for structural/load bearing purposes. You could cast these into an aluminum alloy using lost wax casting method.
comments.author: RossRobotics

comments.text: a 2" over stock lift is trivial at best, and well within the realm of a stock chassis. In the Cherokee, you do not need to even change out control arms for this height (called "Up Country" by the factory).
comments.author: RossRobotics

comments.text:
Thanks for the input.
To help alleviate any FUD:
These are nearly identical copies of a proven item already on the market for at least 20 years that are considered the "first stage" in lifting a coil spring Jeep. That being said, u-joints, bearings, and other mechanical Jeep parts have already been rigorously tested without damage due to this style lift.
As far as testing on streets go, there will be trail testing first. If one DOES fail, the design of the coil spring attachment will not allow the spring to dislodge from the vehicle. It is captured by the bump stop that extends through the center of the spring and this lift puck. The only thing that will happen is the puck could collapse, which would hardly be noticeable. The maximum it could collapse is 2". A tire blowout would be magnitudes more dangerous than this puck collapsing. A 2012 Honda Civic with a 195/65R15 tire has a 4.99" sidewall. A blowout on that car would drop that corner of the car at least 4" AND lose the tire's road holding contact patch with the road. Losing the tire structure is the dangerous part of a blowout, not the upset suspension due to the drop.
I'm an engineer by trade with over 20 years of experience with building custom cars, complete suspension design, and materials fabrication. If this had any chance of dangerously upsetting the suspension in a failure I would not have posted it.
comments.author: RossRobotics

description.text: it's not the same support design, but it does the job!!
This is a derivative of the OpenJSCad iPhone 4 dock, sized to fit an iPhone 5 and the lightning connector.
See the parent thing for details on how to use OpenJSCad if needed.  Some minor cleanup on the hole for the connector may be needed.

comments.text: I made one and changed this:
comments.author: slamzee

comments.text: The phone and connector fit nicely, but the strain relief on the lightning end of the cable needs a little more clearance at the bottom. Thinking of adding a little weight as well, so perhaps a metal base will provide clearance as well as stability...
comments.author: LouFlemal

comments.text: I sacrificed a lightning cable and cut the strain relief very carefully so that I could bend the wire down into the channel. Â Not sure how that will hold up long term but it is working for now.
comments.author: LouFlemal

comments.text: You're right, there shouldn't be too much strain in a fixed dock connection. And when you mentioned the "sacrifice" of a lightning cable, you got me thinking. I decided to take things one step further... A little careful dremel work to lengthen the locking "dimples" along the edge of the lightning connector makes it slide on and off easier for docking use. Add a few rubber feet, and it works great!

description.text:
This is my first test, painting a (very bad printed) pla part.
It is done with nailpolish and water (very cheap), and you can make your own designs. (README.txt is just a meaningless placeholder for the instructions to come.)

What you need: -bowl (large enough to fit your part en then some)
-water
-paint (oil based) or nailpolish ( use more than one color)
-toothpick or somthin similair shaped Optional:
-Acetone (for cleaning parts and paint)
-tape (scotch tape, for taping parts you don't want painted) Allthough this movie is meant for nails, i did the exact same thing for my part. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IF4et6-rw5s&feature=youtube_gdata_player And here is one done with oil based paint (slower drying) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e8JcW1mO5Tc&feature=youtube_gdata_player

title: iPhone SE / 5 / 5S Snap-On Case (tested)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple but fine tuned iPhone 5 Snap-on Back case that should save your new iPhones aluminium back and sides from scratches.
It has a very strong and edgy fit. You probably need to finetune your printer settings to get the correct measurement.
It was already finetuned and optimised. Look out to get the lastest version with the highest number at the end of the file name.

Just print and snap-on. I printed mine with a 0.35mm nozzle and 0.20mm layer height. Best Material to print with is PLA as it is stronger and holds the iPhone better. There are different stls to download:
  • iPhone5Case4 is the first public version
  • iPhone5Case5 has a revised power button hole with a beveled edge for better accessibility and misses the bottom window. Your feedback is highly appreciated. I try to improve more.
  • iPhone5Case6 another revised version with even more clearing on the power button and more bottom clearing at the volume/mute buttons and on the bottom of part of the phone (speakers/lightning). I also moved the back hole a bit to center the apple in it and added another clip for better fitting on the top.
    • Update 2012-09-24: I've uploaded another pic (multi color, all printed in PLA) and also the source file (sketchup) now, as v6 seems to fit very well. I would be really happy if you take the source and make derivates of it. I could imagine having an apple shape instead of the circular one on the back or maybe some other cutout designs with the back side - i hope you all be creative, that's what its for. License changed from "no derivates" to NC-SA - go for it ;-)

comments.text:
I have a solution!
Download the .skp file and open it in SketchUp (Pro or not, it doesn't matter)
Select the model
Under the edit menu, select "Solid group (1 model)", and click on "edit group"
Then, using the select tool, click on the inner edge of the circle (the height) and delete it, so that you can see "inside" the case.
Now, with the line (pencil) tool, draw a line straight across the circle on the top edge, which should fill it in. Erase the lines
Orbit to the bottom and repeat the last step, but on the bottom edge
With the select tool again, click outside the case. You're done!

A tool to tighten/loosen pool caps.

This is a tool to tighten/loosen the pool caps.  One side is for the caps with square heads, the other for the O with the two lines on them.
There are stability tabs at the bottom which should be broken off once printed (they will prevent warping while printing).  The model is 10cm tall, so it should be printable via a maker-bot.  Also, ABS is recomended (I'm not sure what happens when PLA meets chlorine...).
DO NOT SCALE before printing - OK, you may want to scale it up 1% if you find the fitting to tight, but otherwise, the size of the tool matters, and scaling will make it not fit.
Edit: mine broke today, so I modified the design a bit -- made teeth a bit wider/stronger, and the edge of the teeth square to the surface.  Also increased the diameter of teeth.

This is for a Band Director's baton to clip on the side of a podium. I used this cable holder http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=241833 from the customizer app to make the holder.

Based on the Micro-Hexapod (lion) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34796 and the Hexapoduino and the Hexapoduino (pic tux) http://www.instructables.com/id/Hexapoduino-tiny-hexapod-3D-printed-Arduino-cont/ this version fits an Arduino Uno and a ming breadboard on the top and has space to attach a battery holder underneath. The top can be used by itself to make small prototypes or can be connected to the belly to have a walking insect. It has been designed to be used to teach electronics and Arduino to children and adults.

Uses 3 Microservo 9G, depending on your motors you might need 2 separate batteries otherwise the Arduino tends to reboot.
It's better to glue the back legs to the attachments as screwing them is not enough.
